These dogs are proven valuble to the deaf by helping their owner become aware of surrounding noise. Assistance dogs are trained by high standards. They must responde to basic commands most of the time and responde to sounds quickly. The owner must also go through training to be able to work with and take care of the dog. These dogs provide a valuble resource to the deaf, helping with every day life.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: In conclusion, a dog and it's trainer have to have certain capabilities to take care of one another. For the human to receive the dog they must be able to properly take care of it, and this is shown in training. For the dog to pass in training it must do hard work to.For example, a dog has to be able to respond to basic obedience tasks. Although this may sound easy, the dog has to be able to respond to sounds in fifteen seconds. Some of the noises are a phone, a doorbell ringing, sometimes it may even be the sound of a baby's cry. Even out and about in public the dog has to answer to noises such as a honking noise of a car and other traffic noises, when the dog hears these noises the some responses it might give is putting up a paw as if they are ready for a hand shake, or the dog may use a signal more physical.

data_answer: In conclusion, hearing dogs, or "assistance dogs" are very helpful and useful to those who are deaf or blind. These dogs are trained very well to help their deaf or blind owner do something as simple as waking up in the morning, to getting their owner out of their house when there is a fire in their home. Deaf people and blind people who are thinking about getting an assistance dog may be worried about if the dog forgets to help them in a fire or if the dog wouldn't respond fast enough. Well, while the dog gets trained to become a hearing dog, they are trained to respond to a sound within 15 seconds. That's enough time to save a life.

data_answer: You can help those people who require hearing dogs. You can sign up to train a dog to become a hearing or seeing-eye dog. You see, not everyone is blessed with perfect hearing- some can't hear at all. Those people need help, and hearing dogs can help them. A member of your own family might even have one. So, dont think of those unfortunate ones as inferior- help them! Sign up to train a dog, and you will help one who may not be as lucky as you!

The dogs in training or "hearing-ear" dogs are trained to listen to noises such as phone,doorbell,a microwave buzzer,a smoke alarm, or a babies cry. When the person is outside with the dog if the dog hears a noise such as a honking horn or other traffic noises he/she will then put its paw out to try and get in movement or touch with the person that is blind. Before the dog is taken home with the "blind" person it needs to be trained with him/her for about a week or so, so it can get to know the person and have a connection.

data_answer: Many people who are deaf rely on hearing dogs everyday to help them do what they need to do. An example is a scene from the biographical television series "Sue Thomas: F.B.Eye". Sue's alarm clock goes off blasting loud music. She does not hear it though and continues to sleep. Her dog, Levi, hears the noise and jumps onto Sue's bed, telling her that it is time to get ready for work. Hearing dogs are assistance dogs like seeing-eye dogs that assist the blind. They are sometimes referred to as "hearing-ear" dogs. They help people who are deaf tobe aware of the sounds in their environment. They will make physical contant when it hears a sound, then lead them to the source. The dogs are highly trained. They need to respond to basic obedience commands 90% of the time and respond to sounds within 15 seconds.

The dog must maintain a sharp ear and alert the owner whenever a noise is heard, such as a doorbell or a telephone ringing. At first the owner might be cofused, but after a while they willl get used to a dog showing them the object that made the sound. The dog might also make mistakes occasionally. This is to be expected of anything, as everyone makes mistakes. Everyday hearing dogs help many deaf people live their lives.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Sue sleeps soundly on her bed when her alarm clock goes off, blasting loud raock music throught her apartment. Sue continues to snooze, unaware of the noise. Her dog, Levi, hears the sound and leaps on Sue's bed. Alerting her that in fact it is time to get ready for work. Hearing dogs are in the category of "assistance dogs". They are similar to the traditional seeing-eye dogs that help the blind, "hearing-eat" dogs. These dogs help people who are deaf to become aware of the sounds in their enviroment by alerting them to common household sounds such as a phone or doorbell, microwave buzzing, smoke alarm going off, or a baby crying. Dogs can help deaf people in public, noticing sounds such as honking horns and other traffic noises. A hearing dog is trained to make physical contact when it hears a sound and then lead the person to the source, Often dos will lift a paw to the person, as if ready to shake hands. Other times it will be a bit more physical, like Levi leaping onto the bed. In public, the dog will turn to the source of the sound, alerting the person to different things such as vehicles, sirens, or other noise. Dogs in training programs have to meet a high standards. They must respond to basic obedience commands 90% of the time and must respond to the sounds within 15 seconds. The person receiving the dog must also go through training, proving him or her can work with the dog and properly take care of the dog.

If we didn't have "hearing-ear" dogs, then it would effect many people and their lives today.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: A person who is deaf uses "assistance dogs" and are similar to the traditional seeing-eye dogs that help the blind. These dogs are sometimes referred to as " hearing-ear". THese dogs help people who are deaf to become aware of sounds in their environment by alerting them to common household sounds such as a phone or doorbell ring, a microwave buzzer, a smoke alarm going off, or a baby's cry. These dogs also help their owners in public, noticing sounds such as honking horns and other traffic noises. Often the dog will lift it's paw to the person, as if already to shake hands. A hearing dog is trained to make physical contact when it hears a sound and then lead the person to the source. Other times the dog will be more physical, like Levi leap into bed. Dogs in training programs have to meet high standards. They must respond to basic obedience commands 90% of the time and must respond to sounds within 15 seconds. The person receiving the dog must also go through training, providing he or she can work with the dog and properly take care of it.
